8.1.4 to bona fide potential purchasers of direct or indirect equity interests in a Co-Owner, a Co-Owner’s Affiliate or a Phase if, prior to disclosure, such Persons have executed an undertaking of confidentiality not less restrictive than that set forth in this Article 8; and 8.1.5 to a nationally recognized credit rating agency. 8.2 Remedy. The Co-Owners agree that no adequate remedy at law exists for a breach or threatened breach of any of the provisions of this Article 8, the continuation of which unremedied will cause the disclosing Co-Owner to suffer irreparable harm. Accordingly, the Co-Owners agree that the disclosing Co-Owner shall be entitled, in addition to other remedies that may be available, to immediate injunctive relief from any breach of any of the provisions of this Article 8 and to specific performance of its rights hereunder without a requirement to post any bond or other financial assurance with respect thereto, as well as to any other remedies available at law or in equity. 8.3 Use. A Co-Owner receiving Confidential Information in accordance with this Article 8 shall use such Confidential Information, or permit the same to be used by its Affiliates and its and their respective advisors, for the purposes for which it was disclosed in connection with the exercise of such Co-Owner’s rights and performance of its obligations under this Agreement, and for no other purpose whatsoever. 9. CO-OWNER EVENTS OF DEFAULT, REMEDIES AND INDEMNIFICATION. 9.1 Events of Default. The occurrence and continuation of any of the following events at any time during the term of this Agreement shall constitute an event of default of a Co-Owner (an “Event of Default”): 9.1.1 Payment. The Co-Owner fails to pay when due any amounts required to be paid by such Co-Owner under this Agreement, and such failure to pay is not cured within ten (10) days following written notice from any other Co-Owner or the Common Facilities Manager specifying the amount to be paid, provided that such period shall be extended for so long as the allegedly defaulting Co-Owner is disputing in good faith such amount pursuant to the procedures set forth in Section 11.3. 9.1.2 Other Defaults. The Co-Owner fails to cure (a) any breach of the covenants set forth in Sections 6.3 or 6.10, by the earlier to occur of (i) fifteen (15) days following written notice from any other Co-Owner specifying the nature of the failure to perform, or (ii) the date by which such breach is required to be cured to avoid an event of default under the applicable agreement covered by such Sections, or (b) any other failure to perform under this Agreement within thirty (30) days following written notice from any other Co-Owner specifying the nature of the failure to perform, provided that with respect to clause (b), if the default is not reasonably capable of being cured within thirty (30) days, then the default shall be deemed cured if the defaulting Co-Owner commences, diligently pursues, and completes action that remedies the default within ninety (90) days of receipt of such notice. 9.1.3 Seizure of Property. Any substantial part of such Co-Owner’s property is subjected to any levy, seizure, assignment or sale for or by any creditor or Governmental Authority that materially affects that Co-Owner’s ability to perform under this Agreement. 9.1.4 Bankruptcy. If the Co-Owner is adjudicated as bankrupt, becomes insolvent, enters into an arrangement or composition with the Co-Owner’s creditors, suffers permanent or temporary court-appointed receivership of substantially all of such Co-Owner’s property, makes a general assignment for the benefit of creditors, files a voluntary bankruptcy petition or suffers the filing of an involuntary bankruptcy petition that is not dismissed within sixty (60) days after filing. 9.2 Remedies. Upon the occurrence and during the continuation of an Event of Default by a Co-Owner, each other Co-Owner shall have any and all of the following remedies, exercisable only after due inquiry that an Event of Default has occurred and is continuing: 9.2.1 Tender Performance. In its sole and absolute discretion, to cure the default of the defaulting Co-Owner by making or tendering the required payment or performance, and permitting the defaulting Co-Owner’s Phase to remain connected to the Common Facilities and sales of electricity by the defaulting Co-Owner to be continued. If any Co-Owner elects to cure an Event of Default of another Co-Owner, the defaulting Co-Owner shall reimburse the curing Co-Owner for its expenses incurred in rendering the cure, plus interest at the Late Payment Rate. 9.2.2 Disconnect Co-Owner. To require that the Common Facilities Manager disconnect the defaulting Co-Owner’s Phase from the Common Facilities; provided, that the defaulting Co-Owner’s Phase shall be permitted to reconnect promptly when and if (a) the default is cured, and (b) any and all damages suffered and incurred by the non-defaulting Co-Owners have been compensated in a manner consistent with this Agreement and the OandM Agreement, with interest paid at the Late Payment Rate; provided further, that no Co-Owner shall have the right to disconnect any Phase from the Common Facilities other than in accordance with this Section 9.2.2. 9.2.3 Specific Performance. Without limiting Section 8.2, to specifically enforce the provisions of this Agreement. The Co-Owners agree that damages may be an inadequate remedy for an Event of Default under this Agreement and that each Co-Owner shall be entitled to injunctive and other equitable relief against any other Co-Owner, without policy bond or surety, to prevent or eliminate such default. 9.2.4 Other Rights and Remedies. To exercise any and all other rights and remedies which the non-defaulting Co-Owners might otherwise have under this Agreement, at law or in equity. 9.3 Remedies Cumulative. Except as otherwise provided herein, no right, remedy or election given by any term of this Agreement shall be deemed exclusive but each shall be cumulative with all other rights and remedies available under this Agreement, at law or in equity. 9.4 Indemnification by Co-Owners. 9.4.1 Co-Owner Indemnification. To the full extent permitted by Law, each Co-Owner (an “Indemnifying Party”) agrees to indemnify, defend and hold harmless each other Co-Owner and the other Co-Owners’ Affiliates and its and their respective directors, managers, officers, shareholders, partners, members, employees, contractors, agents and representatives (collectively, the “Indemnified Parties”), from and against any and all Liabilities, to the extent arising out of or related to (a) claims of any Person who is not a Co-Owner or Indemnified Parties of a Co-Owner to the extent they arise or result from, or are occasioned by or in connection with (i) any breach by the Co-Owner of any of its obligations under this Agreement or (ii) any negligent, grossly negligent or willful misconduct in relation to the Shared Assets by the Co-Owner or its Affiliates or its or their respective directors, managers, officers, shareholders, partners, members, employees, contractors, agents and representatives; or (b) any breach of this Agreement by the Co-Owner. The indemnification provided under this Section 9.4.1 shall not apply to the extent the Liabilities are caused by the negligence, gross negligence or willful misconduct of the applicable Indemnified Party. In addition, notwithstanding anything contained in this Agreement to the contrary, no Co-Owner shall be responsible for or be required to make payments (including under Article 5) with respect to any Liability due to any negligent or willful act of another Co-Owner or breach of this Agreement by another Co-Owner. 9.4.2 Notice and Legal Defense. Promptly after receipt by a Co-Owner or another Indemnified Party under this Section 9.4 or other parts of this Agreement of any claim or notice of the commencement of any action, administrative or legal proceeding, or investigation as to which indemnity provided for in Section 9.4.1 may apply, the Indemnified Party shall notify the Indemnifying Party in writing of such fact. Upon the Indemnifying Party’s agreement that it shall indemnify the Indemnified Party, the Indemnifying Party shall assume the defense thereof with counsel designated by the Indemnifying Party and reasonably satisfactory to the Indemnified Party; provided that if the defendants in any such action include both the Indemnified Party and the Indemnifying Party and the Indemnified Party shall have reasonably concluded that there may be legal defenses available to it which are different from or additional to, or inconsistent with, those available to the Indemnifying Party, the Indemnified Party shall have the right to select separate counsel to participate in the defense of such action on behalf of the Indemnified Party, at the Indemnifying Party’s reasonable expense. The Indemnifying Party shall not, without the written consent of the Indemnified Party, compromise or settle any indemnity claim unless (a) there is no finding or admission of any violation of Law or any violation of the rights of any Person and no effect on any other claims that may be made against the Indemnified Party, (b) the sole relief provided is monetary damages that are paid in full by the Indemnifying Party and (c) the settlement includes as an unconditional term a complete release of each Indemnified Party from all Liability in respect of such claim. 9.4.3 Failure to Defend Action. Should the Indemnified Party be entitled to indemnification under Section 9.4.1 as a result of a claim by a third party, and the Indemnifying Party fails to assume the defense of such claim or fails to diligently pursue such claim, the Indemnified Party may, at the expense of the Indemnifying Party, contest (or, with the prior written consent of the Indemnifying Party, settle) such claim. 9.4.4 Indemnification Amount. In the event that an Indemnifying Party is obligated to indemnify and hold an Indemnified Party harmless under Section 9.4.1, the amount owing to the Indemnified Party shall be the amount of such Indemnified Party’s reasonable, actual out-of-pocket Liabilities net of any insurance or other recovery actually received. 9.5 Waiver of Partition. The Co-Owners shall not, either directly or indirectly, take any action to require partition of any Shared Assets or compel the sale of any Shared Assets, and notwithstanding any provision of Law to the contrary, each Co-Owner shall (on its own behalf and on behalf of its legal representative, successor or assign) irrevocably waive any and all right to maintain any action for partition or to compel any sale with respect to its Undivided Ownership Interest or Undivided Use Interest, or with respect to any of its Shared Assets, unless otherwise agreed to by the other Co-Owners, each acting in its sole discretion. The Co-Owners acknowledge and agree that they have been paid full consideration for the waiver provided in this Section 9.5. 9.6 Waiver of Consequential Damages. NOTWITHSTANDING ANY OTHER PROVISION OF THIS AGREEMENT TO THE CONTRARY, IN NO EVENT, WHETHER BASED IN CONTRACT, INDEMNITY, WARRANTY, TORT, NEGLIGENCE, STRICT LIABILITY OR OTHERWISE, SHALL ANY CO-OWNER OR ITS AFFILIATES AND ITS AND THEIR RESPECTIVE MEMBERS, DIRECTORS, OFFICERS, EMPLOYEES, AGENTS AND REPRESENTATIVES, BE LIABLE TO ANY OTHER PARTY FOR SPECIAL, INCIDENTAL, EXEMPLARY, INDIRECT, CONSEQUENTIAL OR PUNITIVE DAMAGES THAT ARISE OUT OF, RELATE TO, OR ARE OTHERWISE ATTRIBUTABLE TO THIS AGREEMENT OR THE PERFORMANCE OR NON-PERFORMANCE OF DUTIES HEREUNDER, INCLUDING PRODUCTION TAX CREDITS, INVESTMENT TAX CREDITS AND OTHER INCENTIVES, EXCEPT TO THE EXTENT SUCH DAMAGES ARE INCLUDED IN THE AMOUNTS PAYABLE UNDER THE INDEMNIFICATION PROVISIONS SET FORTH IN THIS AGREEMENT FOR CLAIMS OF THIRD PARTIES FOR PERSONAL INJURY OR PROPERTY DAMAGE. 10. NOTICES. All notices and other communications required or permitted by this Agreement or by applicable Law to be served upon or given to a Co-Owner by another Co-Owner shall be in writing and shall be deemed duly served, given and received (i) on the date of service, if served personally or sent by facsimile transmission (with appropriate confirmation of receipt) to the Co-Owner to whom notice is to be given, or (ii) on date of receipt, if mailed by certified mail, postage prepaid, return receipt requested, or (iii) on the date of receipt if sent by a nationally recognized courier for next day service and so addressed as follows: If to Fowler I, to: FOWLER RIDGE WIND FARM LLC c/o BP Alternative Energy North America Inc. 700 Louisiana St., 33rd Floor Houston, Texas 77002 Attention: Bob Myer Phone: (713) 354-2121 Fax: (713) 354-2120 E-Mail: bob.myer@bp.com If to BP Wind, to: BP WIND ENERGY NORTH AMERICA INC. c/o BP Alternative Energy North America Inc. 700 Louisiana St., 33rd Floor Houston, Texas 77002] Attention: Vice President, Asset Management Phone: (713) 354-2100 Fax: (713) 354-2120
If to Fowler II, to: FOWLER RIDGE II WIND FARM LLC c/o BP Alternative Energy North America Inc. 700 Louisiana St., 33rd Floor Houston, Texas 77002 Attention: Bob Myer Phone: (713) 354-2121 Fax: (713) 354-2120 E-Mail: bob.myer@bp.com If to Fowler III, to: FOWLER RIDGE III WIND FARM LLC c/o BP Alternative Energy North America Inc. 700 Louisiana St., 33rd Floor Houston, Texas 77002 Attention: Bob Myer Phone: (713) 354-2121 Fax: (713) 354-2120 E-Mail: bob.myer@bp.com If to Dominion, to: DOMINION FOWLER RIDGE WIND II, LLC 120 Tredegar Street Richmond, VA 23219 Attention: Scot Hathaway, Vice President – Business Development Tel: (804) 819-2434 Fax: (804) 819-2219 Scott.Hathaway@dom.com 11. MISCELLANEOUS. 11.1 Co-Owner Transfers. 11.1.1 Except as permitted under Section 11.1.2 or in Section 6.2 and Section 11.4, no Co-Owner (a “Transferring Co-Owner”) shall Transfer all or any part of its Undivided Ownership Interest or its Undivided Use Interest in the Shared Assets or any rights or obligations under this Agreement without the prior written consent of the other Co-Owners owning an Undivided Ownership Interest or Undivided Use Interest in the affected Shared Assets Groups. Each Co-Owner hereby agrees that if it Transfers its Phase, then it shall also Transfer its rights and obligations hereunder with respect thereto except as otherwise provided in Section 11.4. All costs and expenses incurred by the non-transferring Co-Owners in connection with any Transfer by a Co-Owner hereunder, including legal fees, shall be borne by the Co-Owner seeking such Transfer, unless otherwise agreed by the affected Co-Owners. 11.1.2 A Co-Owner may Transfer all or any portion of its Undivided Ownership Interest or Undivided Use Interest in the Shared Assets or any rights or obligations under this Agreement to any Person if all of the following conditions are met: (a) such Transfer of all of its rights in the Shared Assets or any rights or obligations under this Agreement is done simultaneously and together with a Transfer of all of its interests in such Shared Assets (and vice versa); (b) such Transfer under subsection (a) above is done simultaneously and together with a Transfer of all of the Excluded Assets of the Phase owned by the Transferring Co-Owner; (c) the transferee has expressly assumed in writing the Transferring Co-Owner’s obligations under this Agreement to the extent attributable to the Transferred portion of the Transferring Co-Owner’s Undivided Ownership Interest and (if applicable) Undivided Use Interest, and obligations hereunder related thereto; and (d) the transferee has executed a joinder to this Agreement substantially in the form attached hereto as Exhibit F. 11.1.3 Any Transfer in violation of this Section 11.1 shall be null and void ab initio. 11.2 Governing Law. This Agreement (including any Dispute) shall be deemed made and prepared and shall be governed, construed and interpreted in accordance with the internal laws of the State of Indiana, without regard to principles of conflict of laws thereof which may require the application of the law of another jurisdiction. 11.3 Dispute Resolution. 11.3.1 In the event of a dispute, action, suit or proceeding arising out of or relating to this Agreement or transactions contemplated by this Agreement, including any question regarding its existence, validity, interpretation, or termination (each a “Dispute”) between the Co-Owners, the Co-Owners shall use all reasonable efforts to reach a satisfactory resolution by referring the Dispute to senior management of each of the Co-Owners. Senior management of the Co-Owners shall meet as soon as possible, on no less than seven (7) days’ written notice, unless specifically agreed otherwise and shall negotiate in good faith. Senior management of the Co-Owners shall examine any submissions by the Co-Owners, and shall, if the Dispute cannot be resolved immediately, agree to convene for further negotiations aimed at resolving the Dispute. Should senior management of the Co-Owners be unable to resolve the Dispute within thirty (30) days after commencement of negotiation by such senior management, then the Co-Owners shall be entitled to pursue any and all available remedies at law, equity or contract in accordance with the remainder of this Section 11.3. 11.3.2 Any Dispute that cannot be amicably resolved by the Co-Owners under Section 11.3.1 shall be exclusively resolved in the Indiana Courts in accordance with this Section 11.3.2. Each of the Co-Owners hereby irrevocably and unconditionally submits, for itself and its property, to the exclusive jurisdiction of any Indiana State court or federal court of the United States of America sitting in Marion County, Indiana, and any appellate court thereof (collectively, the “Indiana Courts”), in any action or proceeding arising out of or relating to this Agreement, or for recognition or enforcement of any judgment, and each of the Co-Owners hereby irrevocably and unconditionally agrees that all claims in respect of any such action or proceeding may be heard and determined in the Indiana Courts. Each of the Co-Owners further irrevocably consents to the service of process in any action or proceeding in such courts by the mailing thereof by any parties thereto by registered or certified mail, postage prepaid, to such Co-Owner at the address specified for such Co-Owner in Article 10. Each of the Co-Owners agrees that a final judgment in any such action or proceeding shall be conclusive and may be enforced in other jurisdictions by suit on the judgment or in any other manner provided by applicable Law. 11.3.3 Each of the Co-Owners hereby irrevocably and unconditionally waives, to the fullest extent it may legally and effectively do so, any objection which it may now or hereafter have to the laying of venue of any suit, action or proceeding arising out of or relating to this Agreement in any Indiana Court. Each of the Co-Owners hereby irrevocably waives, to the fullest extent permitted by applicable Law, the defense of an inconvenient forum to the maintenance of such action or proceeding in any such court. 11.3.4 EACH OF THE CO-OWNERS HEREBY WAIVES, TO THE FULLEST EXTENT PERMITTED BY APPLICABLE LAW, ANY RIGHT IT MAY HAVE TO A TRIAL BY JURY IN RESPECT OF ANY LITIGATION DIRECTLY OR INDIRECTLY ARISING OUT OF, UNDER OR IN CONNECTION WITH THIS AGREEMENT. EACH PARTY (A) CERTIFIES THAT IT IS RELYING ON THE WAIVER CONTAINED HEREIN AND (B) ACKNOWLEDGES THAT IT AND THE OTHER CO-OWNERS HAVE BEEN INDUCED TO ENTER INTO THIS AGREEMENT BY, AMONG OTHER THINGS, THE MUTUAL WAIVERS AND CERTIFICATIONS IN THIS SECTION 11.3. 11.4 Lender Protection. 11.4.1 Co-Owners’ Obligations. Each Co-Owner (a) acknowledges that each Co-Owner may enter into financing documents with one or more Lenders evidencing, securing or otherwise relating to Co-Owner Financing and (b) consents to the collateral assignment under such financing documents of all of such Co-Owner’s right, title and interest in this Agreement to secure such Co-Owner Financing, subject to the terms contained herein, including Section 6.2. As a precondition to exercising any remedies related to any alleged default by a Co-Owner under this Agreement, the other Co-Owners, as required hereunder, shall give notice of default giving rise to such right to exercise such remedies to each Lender that has provided Co-Owner Financing to such Co-Owner at the same time it delivers such notice of default to the first Co-Owner, specifying in detail the alleged event of default and the required remedy. Each such Lender shall have the same amount of time to cure the default as is given to the first Co-Owner and the same right to cure any default as the first Co-Owner. The cure period for each Lender shall begin to run at the end of the cure period given to Co-Owners in this Agreement, but in no case shall the cure period for any Lender be less than thirty (30) days after receipt of the notice of default. The Lender to such defaulting Co-Owner shall have the absolute right to substitute itself for the defaulting Co-Owner and perform the duties of the first Co-Owner hereunder for purposes of curing such event of default. Each Co-Owner expressly consents to such substitution, agrees to accept such performance and authorizes such Lender (or its employees, agents, representatives or contractors) to enter upon the Common Facilities to complete such performance with all of the rights and privileges of the first Co-Owner hereunder. 11.4.2 Defaulting Co-Owner Obligations. Any Lender that does not directly hold an interest under this Agreement, or whose interest is held solely for security purposes, shall have no obligation or liability to any other Co-Owner for performance of a Co-Owner’s obligations under this Agreement prior to the time such Lender directly holds an interest in this Agreement, or succeeds to absolute title to a Co-Owner’s interest. A Lender shall be liable to perform obligations of a Co-Owner to another Co-Owner under this Agreement if it directly holds such interest. Further, in the event that a Lender or its assignee elects to (i) perform a Co-Owner’s obligations under this Agreement, (ii) acquire any portion of a Co-Owner’s right, title or interest in all or any of the Common Facilities or (iii) enter into a new agreement as provided in Section 11.4.6, then such Lender shall not have any personal liability to any of the Co-Owners in connection therewith. Moreover, any Lender or other Person who acquires an interest in the Common Facilities pursuant to foreclosure or an assignment in lieu of foreclosure shall not be liable to perform any obligations under the Agreement to the extent the same are incurred or accrue after such Lender or other Person no longer has ownership of such interest. 11.4.3 Lender’s Right to Possession, Right to Acquire and Right to Assign. A Lender shall have the absolute right: (i) to assign its Lien; (ii) to enforce its Lien and acquire or cause the sale or other transfer of the applicable interest in the Common Facilities at foreclosure by transfer in lieu of foreclosure or any other lawful means; and (iii) to perform all obligations to be performed by a Co-Owner under this Agreement, or to cause a receiver to be appointed to do so. No Co-Owner’s consent shall be required for any of the foregoing, and upon acquisition of an interest in the Common Facilities by a Lender or its designee or any other third party who acquires the same at foreclosure or by transfer in lieu of foreclosure, a Co-Owner shall recognize the Lender or such other party (as the case may be) as the other Co-Owner’s proper successor, and this Agreement shall remain in full force and effect. 11.4.4 Opportunity to Cure. Following acquisition of an interest in the Common Facilities by the Lender or its designee as a result of either foreclosure or acceptance of an assignment in lieu of foreclosure, or by a purchaser at a foreclosure sale, this Agreement shall continue in full force and effect and the Lender or party acquiring title to such interest in the Common Facilities shall, as promptly as reasonably possible, commence the cure of all defaults under this Agreement and thereafter diligently pursue such cure to completion; provided, however, that the Lender or party acquiring title to such interest in the Shared Assets shall not be required to cure those defaults which are not reasonably susceptible of being cured or performed (“Non-Curable Defaults”). Non-Curable Defaults shall be deemed waived by a Co-Owner upon completion of foreclosure proceedings or acquisition of the defaulting Co-Owner’s interest in the Shared Assets by such party. If a Lender is prohibited by any process or injunction issued by any court or by reason of any action of any court having jurisdiction over any bankruptcy or insolvency proceeding involving the defaulting Co-Owner from commencing or prosecuting the appropriate judicial or non-judicial proceedings, then any cure period for commencing such proceedings shall be extended for the period of such prohibition; provided, in no event shall such cure period extend beyond one hundred eighty (180) days. 11.4.5 Termination. Neither the bankruptcy nor the insolvency of a Co-Owner shall be grounds for terminating this Agreement as long as all payments and all other monetary charges payable by the Co-Owner under this Agreement are paid by the Lender in accordance with the terms of this Agreement. 11.4.6 New Agreement. In the event that this Agreement is rejected or disaffirmed pursuant to bankruptcy law or any other law affecting creditors’ rights, then, so long as a Lender has cured any such event of default other than Non-Curable Defaults, the non-defaulting Co-Owners shall, immediately upon request from such Lender received within ninety (90) days after any such event, without demanding additional consideration therefor, enter into a common facilities agreement with such Lender, which new common facilities agreement shall (i) contain the same covenants, agreements, terms, provisions and limitations as this Agreement (except for any requirements that have been fulfilled by the Co-Owners prior to such termination, foreclosure, rejection or disaffirmance), and (ii) be for a term commencing on the date of such termination, foreclosure, rejection or disaffirmance and continuing for the remaining term of this Agreement before giving effect to such termination, foreclosure, rejection or disaffirmance. At the option of the Lender, the new common facilities agreement may be executed by a designee of such Lender, with the Lender assuming the burdens and obligations of the defaulting Co-Owner thereunder. If more than one Lender makes a request for a new common facilities agreement pursuant hereto, then the same shall be delivered to the Lender whose lien is senior in priority. 11.5 Compliance with Laws. This Agreement is subject to all present and future Laws, including valid orders, rules and regulations of any Governmental Authority having jurisdiction over the Shared Assets or the Co-Owners. 11.6 Term. This Agreement shall commence on the Effective Date and remain in full force and effect following the Effective Date until the first occurrence of one of the following: (a) a single Co-Owner becomes the owner of the entire ownership interest in all of the Shared Assets, (b) the mutual agreement of all the Co-Owners, or (c) otherwise as provided under this Agreement. 11.7 Survival. Notwithstanding any other provision of this Agreement, the provisions of this Section 11.7 (Survival), Article 3 (Ownership of Shared Assets), Article 8 (Confidentiality), and Sections 6.4 (Insurance), 9.4 (Indemnification by Co-Owners), 9.3 (Remedies Cumulative), 9.6 (Waiver of Consequential Damages), 11.2 (Governing Law), 11.3 (Dispute Resolution), 11.5 (Compliance with Laws), 11.8 (Headings), 11.9 (Effects of Waiver), 11.10 (Severability), 11.11 (Entire Agreement; Amendments), 11.12 (Not for the Benefit of Third Parties), 11.13 (Counterparts), 11.14 (Further Assurances), 11.15 (Successors and Assigns) and 11.17 (Competing Ventures) are intended to and shall survive termination of this Agreement so as to cover all Claims instituted within the period set forth in the applicable statute of limitations. 11.8 Headings. The descriptive headings of all Articles and Sections of this Agreement are formulated and used for convenience only and are not be deemed to affect the meaning or construction of any such Article or Section. 11.9 Effect of Waiver. The Co-Owners agree that no failure or delay by a Co-Owner in exercising any right, power or privilege under this Agreement shall operate as a waiver thereof, unless such waiver is made expressly and confirmed in writing by the Co-Owner against whom such waiver would be enforced, nor shall any single or partial exercise by a Co-Owner of any right, power or privilege hereunder preclude any other or future exercise thereof. 11.10 Severability. Any provision of this Agreement that is prohibited or unenforceable in any jurisdiction shall, as to that jurisdiction, be ineffective to the extent of that prohibition or unenforceability without invalidating the remaining provisions hereof or affecting the validity or enforceability of that provision in any other jurisdiction. 11.11 Entire Agreement; Amendments. This Agreement constitutes the entire agreement between the Co-Owners pertaining to the subject matter hereof and supersedes all prior agreements, representations, communications and understandings, written or oral, express or implied, pertaining thereto, including that certain Transformer Side Agreement dated January 28, 2009 between Fowler I and Fowler III, which is hereby terminated. Any modifications, amendments, or changes to this Agreement shall be binding upon the Co-Owners only if agreed upon in writing and signed by the authorized representatives of the Co-Owners; provided that any amendment to Exhibit B shall only require the signature of the authorized representatives of the Co-Owners who have an Undivided Ownership Interest in the Common Facilities Group affected by such amendment. 11.12 Not for the Benefit of Third Parties. Except as provided in Sections 9.4, this Agreement is intended to be solely for the benefit of the Co-Owners and their respective successors and permitted assignees, and is not intended to and shall not confer any rights or benefits on any party not a signatory hereto. 11.13 Counterparts. This Agreement may be executed in a number of identical counterparts, each of which shall be deemed an original, but all of which together shall constitute one and the same instrument, notwithstanding that all of the Co-Owners are not signatories to the original or to the same counterpart. A copy of this Agreement signed by a Co-Owner and delivered by facsimile transmission to the other Co-Owners shall have the same effect as the delivery of an original of this Agreement containing the original signature of such first-mentioned Co-Owner. 11.14 Further Assurances. Each Co-Owner agrees to execute and deliver any instruments and documents, and to take such other actions as may be necessary or reasonably requested by the other Co-Owners to effectuate or evidence this Agreement and which are not inconsistent with the provisions of this Agreement and which do not involve assumptions of obligations or materially affect the cost of performance, other than those provided for in this Agreement, in order to give full effect to this Agreement and to carry out the intent of this Agreement, including cooperating in confirming the grant or assignment of property rights or the reservation or retention of property rights by the Capital Contribution and Buildout Agreements. 11.15 Successors and Assigns. Subject to Section 11.1, this Agreement shall be binding on, and inure to the benefit of, the Co-Owners and their successors and permitted assigns. The Shared Assets shall be held, conveyed, assigned, hypothecated, encumbered, leased, used and occupied, subject to the covenants, terms and provisions set forth in this Agreement, which covenants, terms and provisions shall run with the land, and shall be binding upon and inure to the benefit of each Co-Owner and each other person and entity having any interest therein during their ownership thereof, and their respective permitted grantees, heirs, successors and assigns. 11.16 No Recourse to Affiliates. This Agreement is solely and exclusively between the Co-Owners, and any obligations created in this Agreement shall be the sole obligations of the Co-Owners to this Agreement. No Co-Owner shall have recourse to any Affiliate, partner, joint venture, director, shareholder, manager or officer of the other Co-Owners for performance of such obligations unless the obligations are assumed in writing by the Person against whom recourse is sought. 11.17 Competing Ventures. Any Co-Owner may engage in or possess an interest in other business ventures of any nature and description, independently or with others, including the ownership, financing, leasing, management, syndication, investment, brokerage and development of wind energy projects (including projects of the same type and nature as the Project and adjacent to the Project), and no Co-Owner shall have any right by virtue of this Agreement in and to such independent ventures or to the income or profits derived therefrom. EXHIBIT A to Common Facilities Agreement dated June 10, 2009 among Fowler Ridge Wind Farm LLC, BP Wind Energy North America Inc., Fowler Ridge II Wind Farm LLC, Fowler Ridge III Wind Farm LLC and Dominion Fowler Ridge Wind II, LLC
REQUIRED CO-OWNER INSURANCE COVERAGE (ON BEHALF OF ALL CO-OWNERS) 1. Type of Insurance Minimum Limits of Coverage Commercial General Liability (CGL) $1,000,000 combined single limit per occurrence and in the aggregate, where applicable. If CGL insurance contains a general aggregate limit, it shall apply separately to the Shared Assets. CGL insurance shall be written on ISO occurrence form CG 00 01 01 96 (or a substitute form providing equivalent coverage) and shall cover liability arising from premises, operations, independent contractors, products/completed operations, property damage, personal injury and advertising injury, and liability assumed under an insured contract (including the tort liability of another assumed in a business contract), all with limits as specified above. CGL insurance shall include ISO endorsement CG 24 17 (or an equivalent endorsement) which modifies the definition of “Insured contract” to eliminate the exclusion of easement or license agreements in connection with construction or demolition operations on or within 50 feet of a railroad. There shall be no endorsement or modification of the CGL insurance limiting the scope of coverage for liability arising from explosion, collapse, or underground property damage. Umbrella Liability $20,000,000 umbrella liability combined single limit per occurrence and in the aggregate. The commercial umbrella insurance shall provide coverage in excess of the CGL insurance and the Business Automobile Liability insurance. The CGL and commercial umbrella insurance will provide that such insurance as afforded shall be primary as respects any claims, losses, damages, expenses, or liabilities arising out of this Agreement, and insured hereunder, and any insurance carried by the other Co-Owners shall be excess of and noncontributing with insurance afforded by this policy, and shall provide for claims by one insured against another such that, except for the limits of insurance, the insurance shall apply separately to each insured against whom a claim is made or suit is brought. Business Automobile Liability $1,000,000 combined single limit (each accident), including all Non-Owned and Hired Autos. Builder’s All Risk Providing coverage for: (i) Physical damage or loss to property in the course of construction, installation and erection, on an “all risk” basis and including coverage for earthquake, flood, collapse, damage resulting from faulty workmanship, materials and design (LEG 2/96 equivalent), testing of machinery or equipment, debris removal and partial occupancy (if required), with limits sufficient to cover the Probable Maximum Loss (PML). (ii) Delay in Start-up coverage providing coverage for losses caused by an insured peril with an indemnity period of 6 months and a waiting period not to exceed 60 days. The deductible may not exceed $250,000 each and every loss. In addition to the language in Section 6.4.2, coverage shall include waiver of subrogation against (i) Common Facilities Manager and (ii) any contractor providing engineering, procurement or construction services in respect of the Common Facilities, subject to the provisions in applicable contracts with such contractor regarding deductible payment. “All Risk” Property “All Risk” Property Insurance, in an amount equal to the maximum probable loss. The deductible, if any, may not exceed $250,000 each and every loss Coverage shall include waiver of subrogation against the Common Facilities Manager. “All Risk” Property Insurance shall include (i) coverage for fire, flood, wind and storm, tornado and earthquake with sublimits equal to facilities with similar construction location and occupancy to the Shared Assets, with sublimits of no less than $10,000,000 each for flood and earthquake; (ii) Boiler and Machinery Insurance covering all objects customarily subject to such insurance, including boilers and turbines as applicable; and (iii) Business Interruption and Extra Expense Insurance, in an amount required to cover the Co-Owner’s continuing and fixed expenses, resulting from interruption as a result of a physical damage loss, for a period of twelve (12) calendar months. The waiting period deductible may not exceed 60 days. Business Interruption insurance shall cover partial delay of, or interruption in, the operation of the Shared Assets as a result of an insured peril covered under Property insurance as set forth above, to the extent available on commercially reasonable terms as determined by the Co-Owner, subject to a reasonable deductible. Notwithstanding any other provision of this Agreement, Owner shall not be required to have Business Interruption insurance until the Commercial Operation Date.

Assets Jointly Owned or Shared by Phase I, Phase II and Phase III (the “All-Phases Shared Assets”)
A. Common Facilities
The following lines, equipment and facilities (collectively, the “All-Phases Common Facilities”) will be shared by, and constitute Common Facilities for, Phase I, Phase II and Phase III: 1. Fowler Junction Switchyard: A switchyard where the East Transmission Line and the West Transmission Line connect to the Dequine Switchyard-to-Fowler Junction Switchyard Transmission Line, including the perimeter fence around it and all lines, equipment and facilities installed within the perimeter fence of this switchyard, as more particularly described in Exhibit B-1 attached hereto and made a part hereof (collectively, the “Fowler Junction Switchyard”). 2. Dequine Switchyard-to-Fowler Junction Switchyard Transmission Line: The approximately 15.5-mile 345 kV single circuit transmission line with bundled 954 ACSR conductor that will run between the Transmission Line Collection Point and the Point of Interconnection at AEP’s Dequine Substation in Tippecanoe County, Indiana, as more particularly described in Exhibit B-1 attached hereto and made a part hereof (collectively, the “Dequine Switchyard-to-Fowler Junction Switchyard Transmission Line”). 3. Dequine Switchyard: The Dequine Switchyard is not owned by any Co-Owner. However, all costs associated with modifications to this switchyard will be shared as All-Phases Common Facilities. 4. Communications Assets All communication and data lines, equipment and facilities to the extent needed for the respective Shared Assets Groups, including the following items located in and between the Fowler Junction Switchyard, the Dequine Substation, and the Phase I OandM Facility: computers, fiber optic cables, ethernet cables, serial cables, protection systems, patch panels, switches, routers, common RTU (SEL-3351 or equivalent). The following items are excluded from the common facilities, and are considered to be Phase specific: (i) Fiber optic cables and loops to the turbine SCADA system circuits from the East Substation and the West Substation to the turbine circuits, (ii) Dedicated Phase specific fiber optic cables (not carrying common signals or shared with common), (iii) Turbine Vendor SCADA Servers, and Turbine SCADA specific communications items and data switches, (iv) Grid Monitors (Vestas), (v) Patch panels specific to Turbine SCADA systems, and (vi) Radio communications to Phase I met tower #4. Phases I/IIA/IIB OandM Site:
Rights with respect to transmission lines and related equipment and facilities under the following Wind Energy Easement Agreements held by Phase I: Wind Energy Easement Agreement (#209), dated 9/07/07, between James B. Freeland, as grantor, and BP Wind, as grantee, a memorandum of which was recorded in the Official Records of Benton County on 11/19/2007, as Document No. 200700002245, Book 191, Page 1273 (the “Phases I/IIA/IIB OandM Site”).
5. Assets Jointly Owned or Shared by Phase I, Phase IIB and Phase III (the “Phases I/IIB/III Shared Assets”) A. Common Facilities
The following lines, equipment and facilities (collectively the “Phases I/IIB/III Common Facilities”) will be shared by and shall constitute Common Facilities for Phase I, Phase IIB and Phase III:
1. Spare 100 MW Step-Up Transformer: A 100 MW step-up transformer that is to be used as a spare transformer in accordance with Section 3.3.2 including all appurtenances, foundations, spare parts and associated equipment (collectively, the “Spare 100 MW Step-Up Transformer”). B. Shared Real Property
The Phases I/IIB/III Common Facilities are located upon the following real property rights, which will be shared by, and constitute Shared Real Property for, Phase I, Phase IIB and Phase III:
None. II. INTERESTS AND PROPORTIONATE SHARES
A. Undivided Ownership Interest The Undivided Ownership Interest of each of Phase I, Phase IIA, Phase IIB and Phase III shall be set forth in Part B of Exhibit B-2.
B. Proportionate Shares The Proportionate Shares of each of Phase I, Phase IIA, Phase IIB and Phase III, as of the date hereof and as of the final Commissioning Date of all of the Phases, are set forth in Parts A and B of Exhibit B-2, respectively.
[End of the main body of Exhibit B]

EXHIBIT C-1 to Common Facilities Agreement dated June 10, 2009 among Fowler Ridge Wind Farm LLC, BP Wind Energy North America Inc., Fowler Ridge II Wind Farm LLC, Fowler Ridge III Wind Farm LLC and Dominion Fowler Ridge Wind II, LLC WIND INTERFERENCE PROVISIONS AFFECTING PHASE I FROM SECTION 1.7 OF THE PHASE I CAPITAL CONTRIBUTION AND BUILDOUT AGREEMENT: (a) BPWENA shall not, without the prior written consent of Project Company and Phase I Lenders, if any (which consent may be given or withheld, conditioned or delayed in Project Company’s and any Phase I Lender’s sole discretion), construct or install any WTGs (“BPWENA WTGs”) within a distance equal to the greater of one mile or twenty (20) times the rotor diameter of such BPWENA WTGs (the “Allowed Radius”) from any of the Phase I WTG locations shown on [the map attached hereto as Exhibit C-1-A] (the “Phase I WTG Locations”). Notwithstanding the foregoing, BPWENA may install BPWENA WTGs at locations that are less than the Allowed Radius from the Phase I WTG Locations if: (i) such turbine locations are marked “Allowed Locations” on [the map attached hereto as Exhibit C-1-A], and such BPWENA WTGs have a rotor diameter equal to or less than the rotor diameter of the turbines shown at such Allowed Locations, or (ii) Garrad Hassan or another independent wind resource consultant that is reasonably acceptable to Project Company determines in writing that the wake effects caused by operation of BPWENA WTGs to be installed at such proposed locations, in the aggregate, will reduce the total amount of electricity the Phase I WTGs are expected to deliver for sale in a typical year by one thousand eight hundred seventy five (1,875) MW-hours per year or less (i.e. by 0.2% or less of the P50 “Central Estimate” of energy output for Phase I, and the appropriate Phase I WTG manufacturer determines that such wake effects will not cause an increase in design loads that will have a material adverse effect on the expected life of such manufacturer’s Phase I WTGs. BPWENA shall have no liability to Project Company and Phase I Lender for disruption of wind flow or wind resource, wake effects or other wind interference effects, or for increased transmission losses or electrical interference by reason of the installation or operation of BPWENA WTGs as long as they are constructed in compliance with the foregoing limitations (collectively, the “WTG Siting Limitations”). (b) Without the prior written consent of the other Party, neither BPWENA nor Project Company may move any of its respective WTGs from the locations of such WTGs upon the completion of the construction of such Party’s WTGs unless such Party complies with the WTG Siting Limitations as related to the actual location of then-existing WTGs (interpreted in reverse fashion, and without Allowed Locations being relevant, in the case of WTGs moved by Project Company).
EXHIBIT C-2 to Common Facilities Agreement dated June 10, 2009 among Fowler Ridge Wind Farm LLC, BP Wind Energy North America Inc., Fowler Ridge II Wind Farm LLC, Fowler Ridge III Wind Farm LLC and Dominion Fowler Ridge Wind II, LLC WIND INTERFERENCE PROVISIONS AFFECTING PHASE IIA FROM SECTION 1.7 OF THE PHASE IIB ASSIGNMENT AND BUILDOUT AGREEMENT: (a) Phase IIA Impact on Phase IIB. Fowler Ridge IIA and its Affiliates shall not, without the prior written consent of Dominion (which consent may be given or withheld, conditioned or delayed in Dominion’s sole discretion), construct or install any WTGs in Phase IIA (“BPWENA WTGs”) within a distance equal to the greater of one mile or twenty (20) times the rotor diameter of such BPWENA WTGs (the “Phase IIA Allowed Radius”) from any of the Phase IIB WTG locations shown on [the map attached hereto as Exhibit C-2-A] attached hereto (the “Phase IIB WTG Locations”). Notwithstanding the foregoing, Fowler Ridge IIA may install BPWENA WTGs at locations that are less than the Phase IIA Allowed Radius from the Phase IIB WTG Locations if: (i) such turbine locations are marked “Allowed Locations” on [the map attached hereto as Exhibit C-2-B], and such BPWENA WTGs have a rotor diameter equal to or less than the rotor diameter of the turbines shown at such Phase IIA Allowed Locations, or (ii) Garrad Hassan or another independent wind resource consultant that is reasonably acceptable to Project Company determines in writing that the wake effects caused by operation of BPWENA WTGs to be installed at such proposed locations, in the aggregate, will reduce the total amount of electricity the Phase IIB WTGs are expected to deliver for sale in a typical year by 0.2% or less of the P50 “Central Estimate” of energy output for Phase IIB (which, based on the preliminary Siemens layout as attached hereto, is one thousand forty-four (1,044) MW-hours per year, provided that Dominion shall have the right to change such layout, including using different turbines, and upon finalization prior to construction of Phase IIB, Dominion shall provide written notice to BPWENA of the final MW-hour number), and the appropriate Phase IIB WTG manufacturer determines that such wake effects will not cause an increase in design loads that will have a material adverse effect on the expected life of such manufacturer’s Phase IIB WTGs. Fowler Ridge IIA shall have no liability to Dominion for disruption of wind flow or wind resource, wake effects or other wind interference effects, or for increased transmission losses or electrical interference by reason of the installation or operation of BPWENA WTGs as long as they are constructed in compliance with the foregoing limitations (collectively, the “Phase IIA WTG Siting Limitations”). (b) Phase IIB Impact on Phase IIA. Dominion and its Affiliates shall not, without the prior written consent of Fowler Ridge IIA and Phase IIA Lenders, if any (which consent may be given or withheld, conditioned or delayed in Fowler Ridge IIA’s and any Phase IIA Lender’s sole discretion), construct or install any WTGs in Phase IIB (“Dominion WTGs”) within a distance equal to the greater of one mile or twenty (20) times the rotor diameter of such Dominion WTGs (the “Phase IIB Allowed Radius”) from any of the Phase IIA WTG locations shown on [the map attached hereto as Exhibit C-2-B] (the “Phase IIA WTG Locations”). Notwithstanding the foregoing, Dominion may install Dominion WTGs at locations that are less than the Phase IIB Allowed Radius from the Phase IIA WTG Locations if: (i) such turbine locations are marked “Allowed Locations” on[the map attached hereto as Exhibit C-2-A], and such Dominion WTGs have a rotor diameter equal to or less than the rotor diameter of the turbines shown at such Phase IIB Allowed Locations, or (ii) Garrad Hassan or another independent wind resource consultant that is reasonably acceptable to Project Company determines in writing that the wake effects caused by operation of Dominion WTGs to be installed at such proposed locations, in the aggregate, will reduce the total amount of electricity the Phase IIA WTGs are expected to deliver for sale in a typical year by one thousand three hundred seven (1,307) MW-hours per year or less (i.e. 0.2% or less of the P50 “Central Estimate” of energy output for Phase IIA), and the appropriate Phase IIA WTG manufacturer determines that such wake effects will not cause an increase in design loads that will have a material adverse effect on the expected life of such manufacturer’s Phase IIA WTGs. Dominion shall have no liability to Fowler Ridge IIA and Phase IIA Lender for disruption of wind flow or wind resource, wake effects or other wind interference effects, or for increased transmission losses or electrical interference by reason of the installation or operation of Dominion WTGs as long as they are constructed in compliance with the foregoing limitations (collectively, the “Phase IIB WTG Siting Limitations”). (c) INTENTIONALLY OMITTED. (d) INTENTIONALLY OMITTED. (e) Movement of WTGs After Construction. Without the prior written consent of the other Party, neither Fowler Ridge IIA nor Dominion may move any of its respective WTGs from the locations of such WTGs upon the completion of the construction of Phase IIA or Phase IIB, respectively, unless such Party complies with the Phase IIA WTG Siting Limitations and the Phase IIB WTG Siting Limitations, respectively, as related to the actual location of then-existing WTGs. TO BE INCLUDED IN SECTION 1.7 OF THE PHASE IIA CAPITAL CONTRIBUTION AND BUILDOUT AGREEMENT:
(a) Phase IIA Impact on Phase I. BPWENA hereby assigns and conveys to Fowler Ridge II, and Fowler Ridge II hereby assumes and accepts, all of BPWENA’s obligations arising on or after the date hereof to comply with the “WTG Siting Limitations” set forth in Section 1.7(a) and (b) of the Phase I CCBA and all of BPWENA’s rights set forth in Section 1.7(b) of the Phase I CCBA, but only to the extent such obligations and rights relate to the location of the Phase IIA WTGs. Section 1.7 of the Phase I CCBA is set forth in full in Exhibit B [to the Phase IIA Capital Contribution and Buildout Agreement]. (b) Phase IIA Impact on Phase III. BPWENA hereby assigns and conveys to Fowler Ridge II, and Fowler Ridge II hereby assumes and accepts, all of BPWENA’s obligations arising on or after the date hereof to comply with the “WTG Siting Limitations” set forth in Section 1.7(a) and (b) of the Phase III CCBA and all of BPWENA’s rights set forth in Section 1.7(b) of the Phase III CCBA, but only to the extent such obligations and rights relate to the location of the Phase IIA WTGs. Section 1.7 of the Phase III CCBA is set forth in full in Exhibit C [to the Phase IIA Capital Contribution and Buildout Agreement].
EXHIBIT C-3 to Common Facilities Agreement dated June 10, 2009 among Fowler Ridge Wind Farm LLC, BP Wind Energy North America Inc., Fowler Ridge II Wind Farm LLC, Fowler Ridge III Wind Farm LLC and Dominion Fowler Ridge Wind II, LLC WIND INTERFERENCE PROVISIONS AFFECTING PHASE IIB FROM SECTION 1.7 OF THE PHASE IIB ASSIGNMENT AND BUILDOUT AGREEMENT: (a) Phase IIA Impact on Phase IIB. Fowler Ridge IIA and its Affiliates shall not, without the prior written consent of Dominion (which consent may be given or withheld, conditioned or delayed in Dominion’s sole discretion), construct or install any WTGs in Phase IIA (“BPWENA WTGs”) within a distance equal to the greater of one mile or twenty (20) times the rotor diameter of such BPWENA WTGs (the “Phase IIA Allowed Radius”) from any of the Phase IIB WTG locations shown on [the map attached hereto as Exhibit C-3-A] attached hereto (the “Phase IIB WTG Locations”). Notwithstanding the foregoing, Fowler Ridge IIA may install BPWENA WTGs at locations that are less than the Phase IIA Allowed Radius from the Phase IIB WTG Locations if: (i) such turbine locations are marked “Allowed Locations” on [the map attached hereto as Exhibit C-3-B], and such BPWENA WTGs have a rotor diameter equal to or less than the rotor diameter of the turbines shown at such Phase IIA Allowed Locations, or (ii) Garrad Hassan or another independent wind resource consultant that is reasonably acceptable to Project Company determines in writing that the wake effects caused by operation of BPWENA WTGs to be installed at such proposed locations, in the aggregate, will reduce the total amount of electricity the Phase IIB WTGs are expected to deliver for sale in a typical year by 0.2% or less of the P50 “Central Estimate” of energy output for Phase IIB (which, based on the preliminary Siemens layout as attached hereto, is one thousand forty-four (1,044) MW-hours per year, provided that Dominion shall have the right to change such layout, including using different turbines, and upon finalization prior to construction of Phase IIB, Dominion shall provide written notice to BPWENA of the final MW-hour number), and the appropriate Phase IIB WTG manufacturer determines that such wake effects will not cause an increase in design loads that will have a material adverse effect on the expected life of such manufacturer’s Phase IIB WTGs. Fowler Ridge IIA shall have no liability to Dominion for disruption of wind flow or wind resource, wake effects or other wind interference effects, or for increased transmission losses or electrical interference by reason of the installation or operation of BPWENA WTGs as long as they are constructed in compliance with the foregoing limitations (collectively, the “Phase IIA WTG Siting Limitations”). (b) Phase IIB Impact on Phase IIA. Dominion and its Affiliates shall not, without the prior written consent of Fowler Ridge IIA and Phase IIA Lenders, if any (which consent may be given or withheld, conditioned or delayed in Fowler Ridge IIA’s and any Phase IIA Lender’s sole discretion), construct or install any WTGs in Phase IIB (“Dominion WTGs”) within a distance equal to the greater of one mile or twenty (20) times the rotor diameter of such Dominion WTGs (the “Phase IIB Allowed Radius”) from any of the Phase IIA WTG locations shown on [the map attached hereto as Exhibit C-3-B] (the “Phase IIA WTG Locations”). Notwithstanding the foregoing, Dominion may install Dominion WTGs at locations that are less than the Phase IIB Allowed Radius from the Phase IIA WTG Locations if: (i) such turbine locations are marked “Allowed Locations” on [the map attached hereto as Exhibit C-3-A], and such Dominion WTGs have a rotor diameter equal to or less than the rotor diameter of the turbines shown at such Phase IIB Allowed Locations, or (ii) Garrad Hassan or another independent wind resource consultant that is reasonably acceptable to Project Company determines in writing that the wake effects caused by operation of Dominion WTGs to be installed at such proposed locations, in the aggregate, will reduce the total amount of electricity the Phase IIA WTGs are expected to deliver for sale in a typical year by one thousand three hundred seven (1,307) MW-hours per year or less (i.e. 0.2% or less of the P50 “Central Estimate” of energy output for Phase IIA), and the appropriate Phase IIA WTG manufacturer determines that such wake effects will not cause an increase in design loads that will have a material adverse effect on the expected life of such manufacturer’s Phase IIA WTGs. Dominion shall have no liability to Fowler Ridge IIA and Phase IIA Lender for disruption of wind flow or wind resource, wake effects or other wind interference effects, or for increased transmission losses or electrical interference by reason of the installation or operation of Dominion WTGs as long as they are constructed in compliance with the foregoing limitations (collectively, the “Phase IIB WTG Siting Limitations”). (c) Phase IIB Impact on Phase I. BPWENA hereby assigns and conveys to Dominion, and Dominion hereby assumes and accepts, all of BPWENA’s obligations arising on or after the date hereof to comply with the “WTG Siting Limitations” set forth in Section 1.7(a) and (b) of the Phase I CCBA and all of BPWENA’s rights set forth in Section 1.7(b) of the Phase I CCBA, but only to the extent such obligations and rights relate to the location of the Dominion WTGs. (d) Phase IIB Impact on Phase III. BPWENA hereby assigns and conveys to Dominion, and Dominion hereby assumes and accepts, all of BPWENA’s obligations arising on or after the date hereof to comply with the “WTG Siting Limitations” set forth in Section 1.7(a) and (b) of the Phase III CCBA and all of BPWENA’s rights set forth in Section 1.7(b) of the Phase III CCBA, but only to the extent such obligations and rights relate to the location of the Dominion WTGs. Section 1.7 of the Phase III CCBA is set forth in full in Exhibit E [of the Phase IIB Assignment and Buildout Agreement]. (e) Movement of WTGs After Construction. Without the prior written consent of the other Party, neither Fowler Ridge IIA nor Dominion may move any of its respective WTGs from the locations of such WTGs upon the completion of the construction of Phase IIA or Phase IIB, respectively, unless such Party complies with the Phase IIA WTG Siting Limitations and the Phase IIB WTG Siting Limitations, respectively, as related to the actual location of then-existing WTGs.
EXHIBIT C-4 to Common Facilities Agreement dated June 10, 2009 among Fowler Ridge Wind Farm LLC, BP Wind Energy North America Inc., Fowler Ridge II Wind Farm LLC, Fowler Ridge III Wind Farm LLC and Dominion Fowler Ridge Wind II, LLC WIND INTERFERENCE PROVISIONS AFFECTING PHASE III FROM SECTION 1.7 OF THE PHASE III CAPITAL CONTRIBUTION AND BUILDOUT AGREEMENT: (a) BPWENA shall not, without the prior written consent of Project Company, construct or install any WTGs (“BPWENA WTGs”) within a distance equal to the greater of one mile or twenty (20) times the rotor diameter of such BPWENA WTGs (the “Allowed Radius”) from any Phase III WTG locations shown on [the map attached hereto as Exhibit C-4-A] (the “Phase III WTG Locations”). Notwithstanding the foregoing, BPWENA may install WTGs at locations that are less than the Allowed Radius from the Phase III WTG Locations if either of the following conditions is met: (i) BPWENA may install WTGs at locations that are within 10 meters of the locations marked “Allowed Locations” on [the map attached hereto as Exhibit C-4-A], if such WTGs have rotor diameters equal to or less than the rotor diameters of the WTGs shown at the Allowed Locations; or (ii) BPWENA may install WTGs at locations that are less than the Allowed Radius from the Phase III WTG Locations (even if the proposed WTGs are not within 10 meters of the Allowed Locations, or have rotor diameters greater than the rotor diameters of the WTGs shown at the Allowed Locations) if, based on a comparison between (A) the expected wake effects on the Phase III WTGs caused by operation of these proposed WTGs (disregarding WTGs installed beyond the Allowed Radius) and (B) the expected wake effects on the Phase III WTGs caused by operation of WTGs located at the Allowed Locations assuming rotor diameters equal to the rotor diameters of the turbines shown at the Allowed Locations (disregarding WTGs installed beyond the Allowed Radius) (such incremental wake effects called the “Incremental Wake Effects”), the following two determinations are made: (1) Garrad Hassan (or another independent wind resource consultant that is reasonably acceptable to Project Company) determines in writing that the Incremental Wake Effects will reduce the aggregate amount of electricity the Phase III WTGs are expected to deliver for sale in a typical year by three hundred ten (310) MW-hours or less, and (2) the Phase III WTG manufacturer determines that the Incremental Wake Effects will not cause an increase in loads that will have a material adverse effect on the 20-year design life of any Phase III WTGs. BPWENA shall have no liability to Project Company or any Phase III Lenders for disruption of wind flow or wind resource, wake effects or other wind interference effects, or for increased transmission losses or electrical interference, by reason of the installation or operation of BPWENA WTGs as long as they are constructed in compliance with the foregoing limitations (collectively, the “WTG Siting Limitations”). (b) Without the prior written consent of the other Party, neither BPWENA nor Project Company may move any of its respective WTGs from the locations of such WTGs upon the completion of the construction of such Party’s WTGs unless such Party complies with the WTG Siting Limitations as related to the actual location of then-existing WTGs (interpreted in reverse fashion, and without Allowed Locations being relevant, in the case of WTGs moved by Project Company).

record_data.record_plain_text:
Fowler Ridge II Wind Farm LLC
Market-Based Rate Wholesale Power Sale Tariff
1. Availability. Fowler Ridge II Wind Farm LLC (???Fowler Ridge II???), may make electric capacity, energy, and ancillary services available under this Tariff to any purchaser for resale.
2. Applicability. This Tariff is applicable to all sales of capacity, energy, or ancillary services by Fowler Ridge II not otherwise subject to a particular rate schedule.
3. Rates. All sales shall be made at rates established by agreement between the purchaser and Fowler Ridge II.
4. Other Terms and Conditions. All other terms and conditions of sales shall be established by agreement between purchaser and Fowler Ridge II.
5. Seller Category: Fowler Ridge II is a Category 1 seller in the Northwest, Southeast, Southwest Power Pool, and Southwest regions and a Category 2 seller in the Central and Northeast regions, as defined in 18 C.F.R. ?? 35.36(a).
6. Ancillary Services. Fowler Ridge II may make available to any purchaser the following ancillary services:
a. California: Fowler Ridge II offers regulation service, spinning reserve service, and non-spinning reserve service to the California Independent System Operator Corporation ("CAISO") and to others that are self-supplying ancillary services to the CAISO. b. PJM Region: Fowler Ridge II offers regulation and frequency response service, energy imbalance service, and operating reserve service (which includes spinning, 10-minute, and 30-minute reserves) for sale into the market administered by PJM Interconnection, L.L.C. (???PJM???) and, where the PJM Open Access Transmission Tariff permits, the self-supply of these services to purchasers for a bilateral sale that is used to satisfy the ancillary services requirements of the PJM Office of Interconnection.
c. New York Region: Fowler Ridge II offers regulation and frequency response service, and operating reserve service (which include 10-minute non-synchronous, 30-minute operating reserves, 10-minute spinning reserves, and 10-minute non-spinning reserves) for sale to purchasers in the market administered by the New York Independent System Operator, Inc.
d. New England Region: Fowler Ridge II offers regulation and frequency response service (automatic generator control), operating reserve service (which includes 10-minute spinning reserve, 10-minute non-spinning reserve, and 30-minute operating reserve service) to purchasers within the markets administered by the ISO New England, Inc.
e. MISO: Fowler Ridge II offers regulation service and operating reserve service (which include 10-minute spinning reserve and 10-minute supplemental reserve) for sale to the Midcontinent Independent System Operator, Inc. (???MISO???) and to others that are self-supplying ancillary services to MISO. f. Southwest Power Pool: Fowler Ridge II offers regulation service and operating reserve service (which include 10-minute spinning reserve and 10-minute supplemental reserve) for sale to the Southwest Power Pool, Inc. (???SPP???) and to others that are self-supplying ancillary services to SPP. g. Third Party Provider: Fowler Ridge II offers Regulation Service, Reactive Supply and Voltage Control Service, Energy and Generator Imbalance Service, Operating Reserve-Spinning, Operating Reserve-Supplemental, and Primary Frequency Response Service. Sales will not include the following: (1) sales to an RTO or an ISO, i.e., where that entity has no ability to self-supply ancillary services but instead depends on third parties; and (2) sales to a traditional, franchised public utility affiliated with the third-party supplier, or sales where the underlying transmission service is on the system of the public utility affiliated with the third-party supplier. Sales of Operating Reserve-Spinning and Operating Reserve-Supplemental will not include sales to a public utility that is purchasing ancillary services to satisfy its own open access transmission tariff requirements to offer ancillary services to its own customers, except where the Commission has granted authorization. Sales of Regulation Service and Reactive Supply and Voltage Control Service will not include sales to a public utility that is purchasing ancillary services to satisfy its own open access transmission tariff requirements to offer ancillary services to its own customers, except at rates not to exceed the buying public utility transmission provider???s OATT rate for the same service or where the Commission has granted authorization.
7. Compliance with Commission Regulations: Fowler Ridge II shall comply with the provisions of 18 C.F.R. Part 35, Subpart H, as applicable, and with any conditions the Commission imposes in its orders concerning seller???s market-based rate authority, including orders in which the Commission authorizes seller to engage in affiliate sales under this tariff or otherwise restricts or limits the seller???s market-based rate authority. Failure to comply with the applicable provisions of 18 C.F.R. Part 35, Subpart H, and with any orders of the Commission concerning seller???s market-based rate authority, will constitute a violation of this tariff.
8. Limitations and Exemptions Regarding Market-Based Rate Authority. Fowler Ridge II has received (i) waiver of the accounting and periodic reporting requirements contained in 18 C.F.R. Parts 41, 101 (with the exception that waiver of the provisions of Part 101 that apply to hydropower licensees is not granted with respect to licensed hydropower projects), and 141, with the exception of 18 C.F.R. ???? 141.14 and 141.15; (ii) waiver of 18 C.F.R. Part 35, Subparts B and C, except for sections 35.12(a), 35.13(b), 35.15, and 35.16; (iii) blanket authorization for the issuance of securities and the assumption of liabilities pursuant to Section 204 of the Federal Power Act, 16 U.S.C. ?? 824e, and Part 34 of the Commission???s Regulations; and (iv) waiver of requirements under FERC Order Nos. 888, 889, and 890, 18 C.F.R. ?? 35.28, and 18 C.F.R. Parts 37 and 358. See Fowler Ridge II Wind Farm LLC, Docket No. ER09-1655-000; BP Wind Energy North America Inc., el al., 129 FERC ?? 61,207 (2009).
